name: Purpose
description: Why should this research be undertaken? How might it affect the world?
action: Map possible impacts.; Create and share a lay summary.; Solicit a range of lay, expert and peer inputs.

name: Societally Desirable Product
description: Will the products (outputs) be socially desirable?
action: Engage with the public and other stakeholders.

name: Sustainable Product
description: How sustainable are the outcomes? Could they be made more sustainable?
action: Consider the 3 ‘R’s (Reduce, Re-use, Re-cycle).; Apply circular economy principles.; Seek specialist input.

name: People Affected
description: Who is directly affected? Indirectly affected? Who benefits? Who loses out? Is anyone left out or excluded?
action: Map stakeholders.; Consider vested interests.; Consider indirect effects.

name: Research Conduct
description: Is the planned research methodology acceptable? E.g. health & safety, ethical approval & Informed consent, data management, risk?
action: Review local policies.; Access training.; Use local tools and infrastructure.; Seek peer and expert input.

name: Broader Concerns
description: Is the research controversial? Are there alternatives? Is it disruptive? What legislation and regulation apply?
action: Consider public responses to related projects.; Solicit a range of lay, expert and peer inputs.

name: Unintended Consequences
description: What uses could it have? Could it be used to cause harm? What negative consequences might there be?
action: Consider unanticipated outcomes from related projects.; Solicit a broad range of lay, expert and peer inputs.; Consider indirect effects.

name: Equality, Diversity & Inclusion
description: How diverse is the team? What is the gender balance? Are the process and the outputs accessible? Is anyone excluded?
action: Develop an EDI action plan.; Use accessibility guidelines and resources.; Ensure reasonable adjustments are in place.; Consider positive discrimination.

name: Means of Reflection
description: What do you do to reflect on the process? How often do you do this? Who is involved?
action: Convene an advisory board.; Schedule periodic sessions dedicated to RRI.

name: Public Dialog
description: Is the research agenda acceptable? Have diverse voices been heard?
action: Discuss the work at public events.; Talk to organisations who represent relevant groups, such as charities.; Include lay members in any advisory group.

name: Stakeholder Input
description: How do stakeholders shape the product? Are a wide range of stakeholders’ views considered?
action: Employ human-centred design methods such as interviews, focus groups and workshops.; Convene a user/stakeholder panel or advisory group.

name: Stakeholder Involvement
description: Can non-researchers directly influence project decisions? Or shape the research agenda?
action: Involve stakeholders when defining research questions and methods.; Give stakeholder substantive research roles (with support).; Involve stakeholders in project decision-making.

name: Hard to Reach
description: Who is excluded, ignored or discounted? How can they be reached and included? Can anyone else can represent them?
action: Consider specialist support in recruitment.; Work with specialist organisations.
comment: Arguably a second Engage – Product card (I don't have a clear concept for engage-people)

name: Shaping Policy
description: How can we ensure that the future is desirable? How can we contribute to regulation & legislation?
action: Respond to requests for evidence.; Plan an impact campaign.

name: Open Science
description: How do we contribute to open science? Are publications open access? Is anonymous data in public respositories?
action: Check local open access policies and support.; Plan for open access at the start of paper writing.; Deposit anonymous data in open repositories.

name: Organisational Change
description: How can our research structures become more flexible? What infrastructure is required?
action: Raise issues and ideas at an appropriate level, e.g. PI, Department, University Committee.; Share resources and ideas with peers.

name: Training
description: What training is required?
action: Draw on existing training opportunities.; Buy in specialist training.

name: Science Education
description: How do we support science education?
action: Contribute to outreach to Schools.; Contribute to local science-related events.; Develop a specific education/outreach activity.
comment: Separate internally focussed training from public science education (EU RI pillar)

name: Most important; we need to plan something!
